post_text: The 2020-2021 District Calendar is now available! Due to the fluid nature of the COVID-19 Pandemic, we recognize that the calendar of events may be subject to change and that we may need to reimagine, postpone, or cancel scheduled events. Therefore, for the 2020–2021 school year, the District will only publish a digital version of the District’s Calendar. The calendar is prominently displayed on the District’s Website Homepage at http://www.ips.k12.ny.us/. We encourage our families to monitor the District’s website to stay abreast of all important information, changes to the calendar, and updates.

Due to the Tropical Storm Warning, the device pick-up for UPK, grade 3 and grade 4 students scheduled for tomorrow, August 4th has now been postponed to Friday, August 7th during the following times:

Pre-K pick-up is from 8:30-10:00

Grade 3- pick-up is from 10:00-11:30

Grade 4- pick-up is from 11:30-1:00

Anyone who misses the morning pick-up session may pick up his or her device in the afternoon from

2:00 PM - 3:30 PM.

Thank you and have a wonderful evening.

post_text:
Island Park UFSD
2020 - 2021
Curbside Device Pick - Up
Audubon Traffic Circle
Lincoln Orens Middle School

Procedure for Curbside Pick-Up:

1. All devices will be picked up at the Audubon traffic circle in the rear of Lincoln Orens Middle School at the date(s) and time(s) listed below.

2. Parent(s)/Guardian(s) will drive to the designated area and receive their child(ren)’s device(s).

3. Staff members in personal protective equipment (PPE) will be on site to hand deliver devices to each vehicle.

4. To ensure everyone’s safety, parent(s)/guardian(s) and students are directed not to leave their vehicle. This will help to expedite the process in a safe and timely manner.

5. A parent/guardian will have to sign for each child’s device upon receiving it.

6. Families with more than one child in the District, will be able to pick up all of their children’s devices at one pick-up time, regardless of grade-level.

Procedure for Curbside Pick-Up:

2. Parent(s)/Guardian(s) will drive to the designated area and receive their child(ren)’s device(s).

3. Staff members in personal protective equipment (PPE) will be on site to hand deliver devices to each vehicle.

4. To ensure everyone’s safety, parent(s)/guardian(s) and students are directed not to leave their vehicle. This will help to expedite the process in a safe and timely manner.

5. A parent/guardian will have to sign for each child’s device upon receiving it.

6. Families with more than one child in the District, will be able to pick up all of their children’s devices at one pick-up time, regardless of grade-level.

post_text:
NOTICE OF MEETING
As authorized by Executive Order No. 202.1, signed by Governor Andrew M. Cuomo on March 12, 2020, which has been extended by Executive Order No. 202.14, and 202.38 the Board of Education of the Island Park Union Free School District will hold a Special Meeting on July 23, 2020 at 5:30 pm at the LOMS Auditorium remotely by video- conference and/or telephone conference and the public will not be permitted to attend the meeting in-person. It is anticipated that at 5:30 p.m. the Board will make a motion for the purpose of adjourning into Executive Session. No formal action will be taken at this meeting. The public will be able to view and follow the Agenda and see the action taken by the Board on the Recommended Motions. The public will also be able to listen to the meeting in real-time via a live-stream on the District’s website as follows: go to the District’s website (http://www.ips.k12.ny.us/), select Board (located on the left- hand side of the screen), select BoardDocs and then Meetings will appear in the center of the screen with the current meeting date.

post_text:
LIPA-Northport/E Northport Settlement Announced in Newsday

It has been reported in Newsday that the Northport/ East Northport school district has apparently authorized a settlement in principle with LIPA. We are greatly disappointed that they have apparently given up the fight in Court against LIPA without consulting with the Island Park school board and the other stakeholders who have jointly resisted LIPA’s efforts to decimate our tax base. We plan on attending the public hearing Northport is scheduling next week on the proposed settlement and will make our views known. [See: https://www.newsday.com/long-island/politics/lipa-northport-tax-settlement-1.46565390?fbclid=IwAR1RjeOR7zywy0s3kcbGZQNFZiQF_4kd9NBK7j4BiXrQQ0R5FM71zvuwqaA].

post_text:
On Monday, July 6th, the District will be reopening its playgrounds and athletic fields at the Francis X. Hegarty and Lincoln Orens Middle Schools for community use from 8AM to 9PM each day. Community members may enter the playgrounds and athletic fields from the following entrances:

Francis X. Hegarty- Deal Rd. Entrance and Warwick Rd. Entrance

Lincoln Orens Middle School- Audubon Blvd Pre-Kindergarten Playground Entrance, Trafalgar Blvd Parking Lot Entrance, and Baseball Field Entrance

Community members using our playgrounds and athletic fields are reminded that:

· They use our playgrounds and athletic fields at their own risk and understand and accept the risks due to COVID-19.

· Children using the playground structures and athletic fields should be supervised by adults to ensure physical distancing measures are being met.

· Children and adults should wear face coverings.

· Children and adults should wash their hands with soap and water or sanitizer before and after using playground equipment.

Child Care for First Responders & Health Care Workers

IPS will continue its participation in the SCOPE child care program for parents and guardians who are first responders or health care providers in need of child care coverage while at work. This service is from July 1 through August 31, 2020 and it is free of charge. Register by visiting www.scopeonline.us. Go to “Click Here for SCOPE Emergency Child Care.” The host site is:

Rhame Avenue School
100 Rhame Ave
East Rockaway, NY

post_text:
School District and Public Library Budget Vote and Trustee Elections – Gov’s Changes

This morning at 10:30 a.m., the Governor issued an Executive Order extending the deadline for the District to receive absentee ballots by mail for the School and Public Library Budget Votes and Trustee Elections. Absentee ballots will be accepted by the District via the ballot box tomorrow, June 9, 2020 from 7 a.m. until 5 p.m. The District will also accept any absentee ballots received by mail until June 16, 2020 at 5 p.m. The canvassing of the ballots will begin at 5 p.m. on June 16, 2020. The canvassing will be livestreamed. Instructions on how to view the livestream will be available on the District’s website. Please note, no replacement ballots will be issued by the District after June 9, 2020 at 5 p.m.
text:
School District and Public Library Budget Vote and Trustee Elections – Gov’s Changes

This morning at 10:30 a.m., the Governor issued an Executive Order extending the deadline for the District to receive absentee ballots by mail for the School and Public Library Budget Votes and Trustee Elections. Absentee ballots will be accepted by the District via the ballot box tomorrow, June 9, 2020 from 7 a.m. until 5 p.m. The District will also accept any absentee ballots received by mail until June 16, 2020 at 5 p.m. The canvassing of the ballots will begin at 5 p.m. on June 16, 2020. The canvassing will be livestreamed. Instructions on how to view the livestream will be available on the District’s website. Please note, no replacement ballots will be issued by the District after June 9, 2020 at 5 p.m.

post_text: The WebEx meeting scheduled for 6/9 beginning at 5PM to count absentee ballot votes for the school/public library budgets and trustee elections is cancelled; it is now scheduled on 6/16 beginning 5PM as per the Governor’s Executive Order.
text: The WebEx meeting scheduled for 6/9 beginning at 5PM to count absentee ballot votes for the school/public library budgets and trustee elections is cancelled; it is now scheduled on 6/16 beginning 5PM as per the Governor’s Executive Order.

post_text: On Sunday, June 7, 2020, the Governor announced that he will issue an Executive Order extending the deadline for the District to receive absentee ballots for the School Budget Vote and Election. He indicated that absentee ballots can be accepted by hand delivery through 5pm on June 9th and received by mail through June 16th. Once the Executive Order is issued, we will provide more details, including whether the canvassing will still be taking place as scheduled on June 9, 2020.

post_text: Five Island Park staff members were granted tenure during the district's remotely-held Board of Education Meeting on April 21. Congratulations to Stacey Berkowitz (ESL Teacher), Jillian Betancourt (Gr. 5 Teacher), Felicita Carranza (School Social Worker), Ashleigh Fechtig (Special Education Teacher) and Marissa Mendes (ELA Lab Teacher) for achieving this milestone in their Island Park careers! Their dedication to our students and programs is greatly appreciated.

post_text:
District and Public Library Budget Votes and Elections

All deadlines associated with the School District Budget and Election (including the submission of the Nominating Petitions, Campaign Expenditure Statements, Lottery, etc.) are all on hold as they are all based on the date of the School District Budget and Election. In addition, Executive Order 202.13 required that beginning March 31, 2020, the circulation, filing and collection of any petitions that would otherwise be circulated under the Education Law is required to be postponed.

As per Gov, “Schools closed until 4/29; no spring break.” School work continues M-F.

The district recognizes that for many, April 9 and/or 10 are Holy Days. Therefore, students and their families as well as teachers and their families may be involved in religious observance. Nevertheless, as directed by the Governor, lessons will be posted on teacher webpages those days and for all the days originally on the calendar as spring break.

post_text:
Island Park Family Sends Warm Wishes
Students and staff members of Island Park took the time to write thoughtful and heartfelt get well cards to an employee. While community members are practicing safe social distancing, they are closely connected in strength, hope and positive thoughts. The district shares these uplifting messages and illustrations in hopes that others facing COVID-19, near and far, will find some cheer in them.

Grab and Go Meals @ LOMS, 3/30/20

Beginning tomorrow, March 30, we will resume our Grab and Go food distribution program at Lincoln Orens Middle School. Meals are for Island Park children who are eligible for free or reduce price meals. Please pick up your child’s breakfast and lunch meals from 8:30 to 11AM. Thank you Mrs. DeBari, food service staff members, and our custodians who are making this program possible!

post_text:
March 30 Board of Education Meeting Notice

The Board of Education of the Island Park Union Free School District will hold a Regular Business Meeting on Monday, March 30, 2020 at 7:00 PM. As authorized by Executive Order No. 202.1, signed by Governor Cuomo on March 12, 2020, the meeting will be held remotely and the public will not be permitted to attend the meeting in-person. The public will be able to view and follow the Agenda and see the actions taken by the Board on the Recommended Motions. They can also listen to the meeting in real-time on the District’s website as follows: go to the District’s website (http://www.ips.k12.ny.us/), select “Board” (located on the left-hand side of the screen), select “BoardDocs” and then “Meetings” will appear in the center of the screen with the current meeting date. If you have any questions about accessing the meeting remotely, you can contact webmaster@islandparkschools.org or techspecialist@islandparkschools.org. The public participation portion of the meeting will be suspended. The public may submit comments to the contacts listed above.

post_text:
Confirmed Case of COVID-19

Today, March 21, 2020, the District received a call from the Lincoln Orens Middle School employee who notified us last week of COVID-19 testing. This afternoon, the individual told us that the test results are positive for COVID-19. The employee was last at work on March 13, 2020 and will not return to work until an appropriate health care professional determines it is safe to do so. We have been in touch with the Nassau County Department of Health but due to a backlog of cases, they may not be able to confirm the case for us for another day or two. Nevertheless we want you to know what we know. We continue to be in contact with the local and state health authorities and will keep you advised of any developments, including anyone that we believe may have had direct contact with the employee. In the meantime, please be vigilant in the safety procedures implemented by state and local authorities, and join us in hoping for a complete recovery for our employee.

Thank you
text:
Confirmed Case of COVID-19

Today, March 21, 2020, the District received a call from the Lincoln Orens Middle School employee who notified us last week of COVID-19 testing. This afternoon, the individual told us that the test results are positive for COVID-19. The employee was last at work on March 13, 2020 and will not return to work until an appropriate health care professional determines it is safe to do so. We have been in touch with the Nassau County Department of Health but due to a backlog of cases, they may not be able to confirm the case for us for another day or two. Nevertheless we want you to know what we know. We continue to be in contact with the local and state health authorities and will keep you advised of any developments, including anyone that we believe may have had direct contact with the employee. In the meantime, please be vigilant in the safety procedures implemented by state and local authorities, and join us in hoping for a complete recovery for our employee.

Thank you

post_text:
Non-Public School/Private School Transportation Requests

The April 1 deadline (at this time) was re-affirmed by the NYS Education Department as the deadline for Non-Public School/Private School Transportation Requests. At this time, if you are not able to have the form completed by your child's school, you may send an email to our Transportation Supervisor, Kelly Angelo (kangelo@islandparkschools.org), requesting 2020 - 2021 transportation for your child. Please include your child's name, school and grade for the 2020 - 2021 school year. This email request will be accepted in lieu of the application so that you will meet the April 1 deadline. When schools are back and functioning as normal, we will request that the form be completed. Until then the email correspondence will be accepted.

Thank you.

post_text:
Supt’s Message 3-20-2020

I want to update you about the COVID-19 virus and our school community. Please note that we are in contact with the Nassau County Department of Health and as of now, there are no confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the Island Park School community. However, an employee in the Lincoln Orens Middle School, contacted us late yesterday, March 19, and advised us that they had been tested for COVID-19. The results are expected in 3 to 5 days and I will update you further once I receive additional information. The school buildings have been thoroughly cleaned, including the areas occupied by the employee.

In the meanwhile, let’s all remember to practice social distancing as recommended by the CDC. If you or your child do not feel well, contact your physician or call the New York State Coronavirus Hotline: 1-888-364-3065.

Please know that I remain committed to keeping you as informed as possible about any new developments.

Rosmarie T. Bovino, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools

post_text:
Students at Francis X. Hegarty Elementary School in Island Park took a special approach to Valentine’s Day festivities with a tribute to the community’s veterans on Feb. 14.

Veterans from American Legion Post 1029, many of whom are district alumni, visited the building and received a warm welcome in the library. They introduced themselves and discussed their roles as servicemen and servicewoman, and were presented with handmade gifts from the students.

The children and adults then sat together at tables to construct Valentine’s Day cards that they filled with positive messages and illustrated with symbols of kindness and caring. The cards, created from craft supplies and other decorations, were distributed to other veterans on Long Island as a token of appreciation.

The cards, created from craft supplies and other decorations, were distributed to other veterans on Long Island as a token of appreciation.

post_text:
On Feb. 14 Island Park’s Lincoln Orens Middle School participated in P.S. I Love You Day – an annual effort to spread awareness about the importance of mental health. Students, faculty and staff members wore purple in their joint support of kindness, self-worth and self-care in creating a positive school climate and fostering mental wellness.

A Mental Health Team comprised of School Social Worker Allison Janofsky, Guidance Counselor Andrea Porzelt and School Psychologist Colleen Kunz were stationed at a table during lunch periods and invited students to stop by and write positive messages that will be displayed on a bulletin board in the guidance area.

The week leading up to P.S. I Love You Day featured many activities tied to the theme. Announcements focused on mental health and self-care and students were encouraged to make new friends. They also practiced deep breathing for better focus and positive mindsets. This is one of many districtwide initiatives that embrace mental health and good character.

post_text:
Lincoln Orens Middle School’s “Little Doctors” made a big different on Jan. 30 at the district’s annual blood drive. Members of the Student Council dressed the part in scrubs, then took great care of those donating for the New York Blood Center.

The students escorted participants, distributed thank you cards and sent their “patients” home with snacks and juice boxes for replenishment. This event is one of the many ways in which Island Park students do their part in the community and aim to help others.

The Little Doctors Program is organized by the New York Blood Center and is designed for faculty members and students at elementary and middle school levels to increase their knowledge and understanding about the science of blood and the body’s circulatory system as well as to learn about volunteerism and community service.

post_text: Good afternoon. The break in the water main has been identified and is under repair. Our water pressure continues to improve in both school buildings and The American Water Service says that the service will be back to normal within the hour. Thank you.
text: Good afternoon. The break in the water main has been identified and is under repair. Our water pressure continues to improve in both school buildings and The American Water Service says that the service will be back to normal within the hour. Thank you.

post_text: There is a water main break somewhere in the vicinity that has not been identified. This has resulted in limited water pressure in all of Baldwin, E Rockaway, Lynbrook, Oceanside, and Island Park. The American Water Co and Nassau County Police Department are working together with the Health and Safety Officer at Nassau BOCES. We can remain in the buildings (we have running water and are able to flush toilets). However, should the status of the water pressure changes and we have no pressure at all, then we will have to dismiss students. All districts have been advised to take a “wait and see” position for now. We will keep you posted on the website and through our emergency calling system.

post_text:
The Island Park Public Schools is proud to have an ongoing community partnership that involves many annual events. Among them are senior citizen brunch gatherings that are sponsored by the Island Park Recreation Department and take place twice per school year. On Dec. 6, the district welcomed senior citizens into the Lincoln Orens Middle School cafeteria for a warm and festive morning.

Members of the administration and staff attended the event and Superintendent of Schools Dr. Rosmarie Bovino greeted the guests. Food Service manager Dena DeBari and Recreation Department supervisor Keith Manginelli served an array of delicious food, and eighth grade chorus and orchestra musicians performed holiday songs. Transportation Department bus driver, Maryann Russo, delivered guests from Senior Housing to the District and back. It was a cheerful setting that celebrated the sense of family in Island Park.

post_text: 'Tis the season for giving! Student Council members at Francis X. Hegarty Elementary School and Lincoln Orens Middle School have collected many wonderful donations through their toy drives, which run until Dec. 13 and will bring holiday happiness to children in need.
text: 'Tis the season for giving! Student Council members at Francis X. Hegarty Elementary School and Lincoln Orens Middle School have collected many wonderful donations through their toy drives, which run until Dec. 13 and will bring holiday happiness to children in need.

post_text:
The Builders Club at Lincoln Orens Middle School has been busy making a difference in the community. The 17-member group participated in Halloween and Thanksgiving fundraisers, and is now involved in efforts timed with the winter holidays.

Under the guidance of teacher and adviser Karen Davis, the club took part in UNICEF'S "Trick or Treat" campaign in October and raised $358 to help eradicate neonatal tetanus throughout the world. In November, the Builders and Island Park Kiwanis Clubs teamed up at the local King Kullen and collected four overflowing shopping carts of nonperishable food items. The donations were packaged for families in time for Thanksgiving, and the Kiwanis Club also supplied gift cards for turkeys.

Builders Club students are currently creating handmade holiday cards to give to all residents living in Senior Housing in Island Park. They will also hold their annual "Cocoa for Cancer" fundraiser during lunch periods later on in the season.

post_text: Lincoln Orens Middle School eighth graders gathered with Senator Todd Kaminsky and Principal Dr. Bruce Hoffman on Nov. 25 to celebrate the completion of their new outdoor basketball courts. Senator Kaminsky provided a grant that contributed to district funds that helped make this project possible. Students and staff members were excited to express their appreciation. The new courts will be used during physical education classes, recess and for recreational purposes.

They collected non-perishable goods that made Thanksgiving meals possible for others.

post_text:
Francis X. Hegarty music teacher Marie Bluebello-Sambolin and students Rebecca Arden, Emerson Early, Gianna Fabris, John Fandaros, Joseph Henn, Gia Mosey and Chloe Robertson represented the Island Park Public Schools at the 2019 All-County PEAK Music Festival on Nov. 16. The students were also accompanied by parents and grandparents for an exciting musical experience.
PEAK is sponsored by the Nassau Music Educators Association and stands for Parents, Educators and Kids.

This annual event is held for selected fourth grade musicians throughout Nassau County and provides a Saturday morning filled with musical workshops in which parents, educators and students have unique opportunities to make music together.
The Hegarty students and their chaperones enjoyed sessions in folk dancing and Australian rhythms. They all sang as part of the event as well.
